citation.article-title: Verminephrobacter eiseniae gen. nov., sp. nov., a nephridial symbiont of the earthworm Eisenia foetida (Savigny).
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Verminephrobacter [Ver.mi.ne.phro′bac.ter. L. n. vermis a worm; Gr. n. nephros a kidney; N.L. masc. n. bacter a rod; N.L. masc. n. Verminephrobacter earthworm-kidney (associated) bacteria].
They occur singly or in doublets and are flagellated, but motility is seldom observed under standard culturing conditions.
Obligate aerobic growth with a preference for low oxygen tensions.
Oxidative metabolism occurs with oxygen as the terminal electron acceptor.
Moderate growth is obtained on complex media containing pyruvate and amino acids.
Ammonium salts, urea and nitrate can serve as nitrogen sources in defined media.
Biotin is required for growth on defined mineral medium in the absence of amino acids.
A cyclopropane-substituted fatty acid (cyclo C17 : 0) is present as a major component of membrane-derived fatty acid methyl esters in all strains tested.
The DNA G+C content is 67 mol%.
The genus Verminephrobacter comprises nephridium-associated bacterial symbionts of lumbricid earthworm species.
The type species is Verminephrobacter eiseniae.
